Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesions involving:
- right optic nerve and right midbrain.

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included Multiple sclerosis.

Other possible differentials:
- NMOSD (AQP4+), MOGAD, Neurosarcoid, SLE and Neurosyphilis.
- Also feasible but of low probability: Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, TB, Vasculitis, Sjogren's, ADEM, Behçet's, Lymphoma and Lyme.

The following suggested diagnoses have a low probability of providing a unifying explanation for the full clinical presentation:
- Right posterior circulation ischaemic stroke involving the midbrain (posterior cerebral artery branch infarct) (plausible for unilateral brainstem; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Right posterior communicating artery aneurysm or parasellar/tentorial mass compressing the right optic nerve and midbrain (atypical for unilateral brainstem and unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Right midbrain haemorrhage (e.g. cavernous malformation or hypertensive bleed) (plausible for unilateral brainstem; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Intrinsic right midbrain tumour (e.g. glioma or metastasis) (plausible for unilateral brainstem; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)

ft_diagnoses_raw: Right posterior circulation ischaemic stroke involving the midbrain (posterior cerebral artery branch infarct)
Right posterior communicating artery aneurysm or parasellar/tentorial mass compressing the right optic nerve and midbrain
Right midbrain haemorrhage (e.g. cavernous malformation or hypertensive bleed)
Multiple sclerosis with right optic neuritis and right midbrain plaque
Intrinsic right midbrain tumour (e.g. glioma or metastasis)
additional_diagnoses: Right posterior circulation ischaemic stroke involving the midbrain (posterior cerebral artery branch infarct)
Right posterior communicating artery aneurysm or parasellar/tentorial mass compressing the right optic nerve and midbrain
Right midbrain haemorrhage (e.g. cavernous malformation or hypertensive bleed)
Intrinsic right midbrain tumour (e.g. glioma or metastasis)

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---

- Agree with the suggested MRI including the Brain and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands - would potentially inform a diagnosis/details of multiple sclerosis.

But incomplete, should also consider: MRI Orbits.

To evaluate other differential diagnoses:
- Agree with considering: ANA, CRP, ENA, ACE, HIV, ANCA, syphilis, ESR.
- Could also consider testing: anti-dsDNA, anti-MOG, TB, anti-AQP4, lyme, CSF (flow cytometry and cytology).

ft_proposed_investigations: MRI brain with and without contrast including diffusion-weighted imaging
MR angiography of intracranial and neck vessels
CT angiogram of head and neck (if MR angiography not immediately available or to clarify aneurysm anatomy)
Formal ophthalmological assessment including visual acuity, colour vision and dilated fundus examination
Optical coherence tomography of retinal nerve fibre layer
Lumbar puncture with CSF cell count, protein, glucose, oligoclonal bands and IgG index (after mass lesion and raised intracranial pressure are excluded)
Chest CT or whole-body imaging for occult malignancy if tumour suspected

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Appropriate to consider but delay treatment.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Presenting complaint is not specified, so no indication what the current issue is and whether neurological signs are new or old.

- Timing of current symptoms not specified, so no indication whether this is a recent issue or old deficit.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

DMTs: Appropriate to consider but delay treatment.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.

- Need to know comorbidities to ensure no contraindications to immunosuppression.

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Admit to high-dependency or stroke unit with close neurological and cardiorespiratory monitoring
reasons: Brainstem involvement risks sudden deterioration in consciousness, respiration and airway protection
Allows frequent neurological observations and rapid response to any worsening

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Airway, breathing and circulation optimisation including supplemental oxygen if needed, blood pressure and glucose control, and temperature management
reasons: Physiological optimisation reduces secondary brain injury in acute CNS lesions
Posterior circulation strokes and brainstem masses are highly sensitive to alterations in perfusion and oxygenation

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Nil by mouth until formal swallowing assessment and institution of aspiration precautions
reasons: Brainstem pathology and left hemiparesis increase risk of dysphagia and silent aspiration
Prevents aspiration pneumonia while definitive assessment is arranged

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Mechanical venous thromboembolism prophylaxis (e.g. intermittent pneumatic compression) and, once haemorrhage is excluded, pharmacological prophylaxis with low-dose low-molecular-weight heparin if not contraindicated
reasons: Hemiparesis and reduced mobility substantially increase VTE risk
Early prophylaxis reduces risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Intravenous thrombolysis and/or endovascular thrombectomy as per acute ischaemic stroke protocol if imaging confirms an eligible posterior circulation infarct within treatment window
reasons: Requires prior neuroimaging to confirm ischaemic stroke and exclude haemorrhage or mass
Eligibility depends on time of onset, infarct extent, and absence of contraindications

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Endovascular coiling or surgical clipping of a posterior communicating or basilar tip aneurysm if demonstrated
reasons: Definitive treatment for compressive aneurysm causing third nerve palsy and brainstem compromise
Requires angiographic confirmation and multidisciplinary neurosurgical/neurointerventional planning

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone followed by an oral taper if MRI and CSF support an acute demyelinating relapse (e.g. multiple sclerosis)
reasons: Steroids can shorten duration and severity of acute demyelinating attacks
Should not be started before excluding infection, mass lesion and vascular causes

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Early multidisciplinary rehabilitation (physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech and language therapy)
reasons: Initiated once patient is medically stable to improve motor recovery, gait and coordination
Addresses functional deficits from left hemiparesis and cerebellar ataxia and reduces long-term disability

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Long-term secondary prevention tailored to final diagnosis (antiplatelet or anticoagulation for stroke, management of vascular risk factors, or disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis)
reasons: Reduces risk of recurrence or progression of the underlying disorder
Choice of agent depends on whether the final aetiology is vascular, demyelinating or neoplastic

ft_plan.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone followed by an oral taper if MRI and CSF support an acute demyelinating relapse (e.g. multiple sclerosis)
reasons: Steroids can shorten duration and severity of acute demyelinating attacks
Should not be started before excluding infection, mass lesion and vascular causes
